docs.lead_paragraph: Like tilting a pinball machine, leaning on the rails of a stair climber comes with a penalty -- even if it is just for a short rest. Dr. J. W. Yates, co-author of a recent study presented at a sports medicine conference this summer, showed that the common form of exercise cheating made the workout less strenuous. For a high intensity workout, minimal leaning by 12 subjects decreased their oxygen intake by 7.3 percent and their heart rates by 4.2 percent.

headline.main: Stair Climbers and Leaning: Tilt Penalty

docs.abstract: Leaning on one's stair climber reduces the amount of calories one can expect to burn during an exercise period; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical researchers have long done experiments either ''in vivo'' (living organisms) or ''in vitro'' (in glass or test tubes). Now they are starting to work ''in silico,'' or in computers. In a marriage of biotech and high tech, computers are beginning to transform the way drugs are developed, from the earliest stage of drug discovery to the late stage of testing the drugs in people.

headline.main: Drug Testers Turn to 'Virtual Patients' as Guinea Pigs

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Nancy Frick, one of the world's foremost experts on the long-term psychological effects of childhood polio, says she has a classic Type-A personality: driven to succeed, often to the point of exhaustion, and unduly afraid of failure. And it is precisely these characteristics that have made her, in a sense, the laboratory for her research into post-polio syndrome -- a late effect of poliomyelitis. The public knows little about the centuries-old illness and its painful and fatiguing effects. Post-polio syndrome remains obscure largely because so many who suffer from it are reluctant to look back at such a dark part of their past, and, unlike Dr. Frick, 55, are unwilling to talk about it.

headline.main: A First-Person Study of Polio's Painful Legacy

docs.abstract: Dr Nancy Frick, director of Harvest Center and one of the world's foremost experts on the long-term psychological effects of childhood polio, is herself one of the 440,000 people who have experienced severe effects of polio decades after they thought they had conquered it; her experience with polio and the sometimes brutal treatments for it and her long-term psychological reaction to both are central to a new understanding of polio and its consequences; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten mothers with babies nearby in strollers jumped up and down in unison on the steps around the Alice in Wonderland statue in Central Park, as their babies slept. Sweat poured off Elizabeth Firestone as she peered into the stroller at her sleeping 3-month-old twins, Henry and Jack. ''This is the only time in my day that they'll sleep at the same time,'' she said, out of breath. Mrs. Firestone, a 36-year-old child psychiatrist, has become a regular at Strollercize, a rapidly growing fitness program that started four years ago when one woman in the park tried to coax mothers off park benches to join her workout. It has expanded to include more than 150 classes a month, two indoor facilities and a new national licensing program.

headline.main: Babies on Sideline as Mothers Work Out

docs.abstract: New mothers exercise together in Central Park with the babies in strollers nearby; exercise is seen as good way to recover from pregnancy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Osteoporosis is a silent disease. Just as a heart attack is often the first clue to the existence of atherosclerosis, a fracture is usually the first indication that a person's bones have become dangerously weakened. But it doesn't have to be that way. According to guidelines issued last week by the National Osteoporosis Foundation, it is now possible to determine a person's propensity for fracture far in advance and offer preventive treatments for most people at risk of developing osteoporosis. This is not a problem to be dismissed lightly. Osteoporosis is responsible for about 1.5 million fractures a year that incur medical costs of $38 million each day. An estimated 28 million Americans have already lost enough bone to be at great risk of suffering a fracture. Half of all women over 50 and one in eight men over 50 will suffer an osteoporosis-related fracture in their lifetimes. And when the fracture involves the hip, as it does in 300,000 people a year, it is fatal in 20 percent of cases.

headline.main: Guidelines Offer an Earlier Blueprint for the Battle Against Bone Loss

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on guidelines developed by National Osteoporosis Foundation for determining who should get bone density tests based on their risk factors for developing the disease; notes that primary risk factors are a history of bone fracture as an adult, a history of fracture in a parent or sibling, cigarette smoking and having a small, thin frame; also notes its recommendations for improving bone density; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Biologists have taken a first step toward cracking the code of the parasite that causes malaria and using the information to explore all the deadly organism's biological weaknesses. The first of the parasite's 14 chromosomes has been fully sequenced, meaning the order of its DNA units has been determined, by scientists at the Institute for Genomic Research in Rockville, Md., and other institutions.
docs.abstract: Scientists at Institute for Genomic Research and elsewhere begin sequencing genome of the protozoan that causes malaria; hope to use the information to explore the organism's biological weaknesses, which could then be targeted by new drugs (M)
docs.snippet: Biologists have taken a first step toward cracking the code of the parasite that causes malaria and using the information to explore all the deadly organism's biological weaknesses.    The first of the parasite's 14 chromosomes has been fully...

docs.lead_paragraph: Hopeful of finding clues to a better understanding of obesity and other disorders, scientists have long been interested in why people start and stop eating. For the most part, researchers have assumed the answers have to do with physiology: caloric content, taste, and the functioning of brain centers involved in hunger and satiety. A new study, however, suggests that cultural context -- in particular the memory of when a person last ate and how much was consumed -- plays an equally important role.

headline.main: Study Links Food Desire To Memory

docs.abstract: Research with severe amnesiacs at University of Pennsylvania suggests that the memory of when a person last ate and how much was consumed plays an important role in determining why people start and stop eating; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: Hopeful of finding clues to a better understanding of obesity and other disorders, scientists have long been interested in why people start and stop eating.    For the most part, researchers have assumed the answers have to do with physiology:...

docs.lead_paragraph: Though gluttony is cited in the Bible as a sin and a sign of moral weakness, religious people in the United States are more likely to be overweight than nonreligious people, researchers from Purdue University have found. In a state-by-state comparison, the researchers found that obesity is most prevalent in states where religious affiliation is most common, like Michigan, Mississippi and Indiana.

headline.main: More Faith, More Pounds, More Secure

docs.abstract: Purdue University study finds obesity to be more prevalent among religious Americans than among the nonreligious; however, the religious report higher levels of well-being than the nonreligious (S)
docs.snippet: Though gluttony is cited in the Bible as a sin and a sign of moral weakness, religious people in the United States are more likely to be overweight than nonreligious people, researchers from Purdue University have found.    In a state-by-state...

docs.lead_paragraph: The question, Henry Higgins, is not ''why can't a woman be more like a man'' but why isn't a woman more like a man. That is what medical researchers want to know so that they can become better equipped to head off health problems to which woman are especially vulnerable. While it is true that women outlive men by about eight years on average, it is also true that when it comes to several leading ailments that afflict both men and women, the fairer sex fares worse.

headline.main: Some Ailments Found Guilty of Sex Bias

docs.abstract: Society for Advancement of Women's Health Research releases analysis of disease and disease treatments showing some striking differences in how men and women fare; although women outlive men by about eight years on average, they do not do as well as men when it comes to several leading ailments that affect both sexes (M)
docs.snippet: The question, Henry Higgins, is not ''why can't a woman be more like a man'' but why isn't a woman more like a man. That is what medical researchers want to know so that they can become better equipped to head off health problems to which woman are...

docs.lead_paragraph: When the history of women's bodybuilding is written, 1998 will emerge as the year that the weights tipped in favor of the sport's old nemesis, femininity. In the 20 years since women began publicly showing off their muscles in earnest, this issue -- whether the muscles that make the man also make the woman manly -- has hewn the sport more than any other. What has happened this year might have seemed, to some, inevitable: Fitness competition, a slenderized version of women's bodybuilding, has eclipsed some of the bulked-up muscle shows in participant and audience popularity.
docs.abstract: Fitness competition, a slenderized version of women's bodybuilding, is stealing participants and audiences from the shows featuring women with bulked-up physiques; male fitness events are also starting up and are expected to attract more participants than traditional bodybuilding competitions; photos (M)
